awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Geologic Methane Emissions to the Atmosphere--Improving the Bottom-Up Estimates of Microseepage
awd_abstract_narration:
Methane (CH4) is a powerful greenhouse gas that contributes to warming of the atmosphere and climate change and has significant societal implications. Nevertheless, relative magnitudes of its numerous sources remain ill-constrained. In the present study, field observations are collected of CH4 that is emitted from natural geological features and represent one of the most uncertain sources of CH4 to the atmosphere. Machine learning techniques are then used to increase predictive power of these emissions across the United States. Undergraduate and graduate students are an integral part of the field sampling and data analysis components of the work, and educational outreach activities are intended through established programs with the local school district and Rochester Museum & Science Center.

Microseepage is a low-intensity flux of natural geological CH4 to the atmosphere that is postulated to be the single largest, yet poorly constrained component of geological emissions. The research seeks to improve bottom-up estimates of microseepage from large areas of hydrocarbon-rich sedimentary basins, with the overarching hypothesis that microseepage emissions in existing inventories are overestimated. CH4 fluxes are determined during summer and winter in eight different US basins to cover a wide area of varying characteristics in gas reservoir depth, structure/tectonics, and climate/ecosystem. A field deployable closed dynamic flux chamber technique is used for these measurements. The relationship between microseepage flux magnitude and a set of hypothesized flux-enhancing parameters is then investigated and used to develop a machine-learning approach for upscaling microseepage fluxes. Resulting new estimates of microseepage CH4 emissions from the contiguous US will improve our understanding of natural emissions of this important greenhouse gas that is also a key player in atmospheric chemistry and global climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The magnitude of the natural geological methane (CH4) source is highly uncertain. Recent bottom-up studies have estimated this source at ≈50 Teragrams of methane per year (Tg CH4 yr-1), or ≈9% of the total global methane emissions to the atmosphere. In contrast, recent topdown constraints from measurements of 14C in methane in preindustrial air from ice cores suggest that natural geological methane emissions are an order of magnitude lower. This large disagreement also presents an obstacle for top-down studies of the magnitude of the anthropogenic fossil methane source, because natural geologic and anthropogenic fossil emissions have similar isotopic signatures and are often co-located. The most recent bottom-up assessment provided a globally gridded emission inventory and postulated that microseepage is the single largest component of the natural geological source, amounting to 24 Tg CH4 yr-1 globally. In that assessment, the contiguous US was an important contributor to microseepage emissions, accounting for ≈25% of the global total. However, this bottom-up estimate was based on limited data and employed a crude upscaling approach underpinned by untested assumptions. New measurements were recently used to test the bottom-up inventory in Western NY, USA (an area with relatively high predicted fluxes) and the results suggest that microseepage for this region has been overestimated by several orders of magnitude. This project work would strongly improve bottom-up estimates of microseepage through 1) more than doubling the number of available microseepage measurements, 2) providing the first quantitative investigation of the relationship between microseepage flux magnitude and local- and basin-scale predictive parameters and 3) using a state-of-the-art machine learning approach to analyze the results and upscale the emissions.

 

The research goals for this project were to improve bottom-up estimates of natural geological methane emissions, with a focus on microseepage. Microseepage is the low-intensity flux of methane to the atmosphere over large areas of hydrocarbon-rich sedimentary basins. The field measurement component of the project focused on five basins in the contiguous US. These basins span a large range of variability in key parameters that are hypothesized to be important for microseepage (gas reservoir depth, structure / tectonics, and climate / ecosystem). A GIS database of local-scale predictive parameters such as locations of active oil and gas seeps, previously drilled wells, sedimentary layer outcrops, geologic faults, and seismicity was assembled. A sampling strategy for each basin was then developed to ensure representative coverage of areas that are expected to have high, intermediate and low microseepage fluxes, as well as to ensure inter-comparability of results between basins. Hundreds of microseepage fluxes were measured using a closed dynamic flux chamber technique, with measurements during both the summer and winter seasons and multiple repeated measurements at sites with significant positive fluxes to investigate temporal variability. Results of this effort were presented by undergraduate-student lead authors at the fall American Geophysical Union meetings in 2021, 2022 and 2023. In general, we found microseepage to be highly variable in space and time. Microseepage tended to occur locally near coal outcrops and was often spatially related to macroseeps. In some basins seepage intensity was higher in winter compared to summer, possibly due to cold surface soils reducing the biofilter effect of microbial oxidation. The results will be analyzed with a machine-learning approach to determine quantitative relationships between microseepage flux and basin-scale and local-scale predictive parameters, and upscaled to an estimate of total microseepage methane flux for the contiguous US for publication in peer-reviewed manuscripts. Senior scientists on the project trained and supervised a number of graduate and undergraduate students. Project participants gave presentations at universities and to the general public on issues of natural geologic methane emissions, summarizing the state of knowledge and research on this topic. Beyond science and technology, improved estimates of geologic methane emissions will very likely result in improved estimates of anthropogenic fossil methane emissions. This information could help inform climate policy and mitigation efforts.
